review.title: Together We Know How to Achieve: An Epistemic Logic of Know-How
review.abstract: The existence of a coalition strategy to achieve a goal does not necessarily mean that the coalition has enough information to know how to follow the strategy. Neither does it mean that the coalition knows that such a strategy exists. The article studies an interplay between the distributed knowledge, coalition strategies, and coalition "know-how" strategies. The main technical result is a sound and complete trimodal logical system that describes the properties of this interplay.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: An agent a arrives at a fork in the road. There is a sign saying that one of the two roads leads to prosperity, another to death. The agent must take the fork in the road, but it does not know which road leads to where. Does the agent have a strategy to get to prosperity? Since one of the two roads leads to prosperity, such a strategy clearly exists. We call this fact by the modal formula Sap, where statement p is a claim to future prosperity. Furthermore, agent a knows that such a strategy exists. We write this as KaSap. But the agent does not know what the strategy is and therefore does not know how to apply the strategy. We call this per ¬ Hap, where the know-how modality Ha expresses the fact that agent a knows how to reach the goal based on the information available to it. In this article we examine the interplay between modality K, which represents knowledge, modality S, which represents the existence of a strategy, and modality, which represents the existence of a know-how strategy.

sections.heading: 1.4 Coalitions
sections.text: We have talked about strategies, know-how and the knowledge of individual actors. In this article we look at knowledge, strategies and know-how strategies of coalitions. There are several forms of group knowledge that have already been studied before, the two most popular of which are general knowledge and distributed knowledge [8]. Different contexts require different forms of group knowledge. As in the famous problem of the two generals [4, 11], where communication channels between the actors are unreliable, the creation of common knowledge between the actors might be indispensable for a strategy. In some contexts, the distinction between general and distributed knowledge is meaningless. For example, if members of a political group share all their information and develop a common strategy, then the shared knowledge of the members becomes the common knowledge of the group during the face-to-face meeting. Finally, in some other situations, the distributed knowledge makes more sense than the general knowledge.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this article, we have proposed a solid and complete logic system that captures an interplay between distributed knowledge, coalition strategies, and how-to strategies. In future work, we hope to explore know-how strategies of inhomogeneous coalitions in which different members contribute differently to the goals of the coalition. For example, "incognito" members of a coalition could contribute only by sharing information, while "open" members also contribute by voting.
